results.title: Close harmony
results.brief_description: An inspiring documentation of the work of music teacher Arlene Symons in bringing together a chorus of children from the 1979-1980 class of the Friends School in Brooklyn, New York and the senior chorus from the Council Centre for Senior Citizens, Brooklyn. Three months of separate rehearsals took place, and a pen pal program set up between the two groups. A week before the concert, the groups came together.

results.title: Close-up
results.creator_credit: Abbas Kiarostami, Sacher Film and Canal+
results.brief_description: Abbas Kiarostami’s (‘The Taste of Cherry’, ‘Through the Olive Trees’) ‘Close-Up’ is part of a remarkable body of films from Iran that address, in very original ways the artifice of cinema and the uneasy junction between life and art. Approached like a documentary, ‘Close-Up’ tells the true story of Hossein Sabzian, an unemployed movie buff who is mistaken for renowned Iranian director Mohsen Makmalbaf (‘Gabbeh’, ‘Moment of Innocence’), and decides to take the misunderstanding further, by deceiving a middle-class Iranian Family. Eventually his fraudulence is exposed and he is faced with a potential jail term. Blurring the line between fact and fiction further is Kiarostami himself who interviews the protagonists involved in this unbelievable story, culminating in Sabzian’s trial which Kiarostami films. Interestingly enough, Makmalbaf (who appears in ‘Close-Up’), has his own freakish experience of truth informing fiction, which became the subject matter for his wonderful film ‘Moment of Innocence’. ‘Close-Up’ also features a short by Italian director Nanni Moretti, called “The Day of the Premiere of ‘Close-Up’”, which pays humorous tribute to Kiarostami and ‘Close-Up’. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: Clone Inc.
results.creator_credit: Louise Vandelac, Karl Parent, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Clone Inc is a critical documentary which discusses the issues of human reproductive technology, particularly the cloning of embryos, and its scientific, psychological and philosophical implications. In its focus on the advocates of human cloning, such as Clone Rights United Front and the religious cult with visions of duplicating their leader’s genes, the Raelians, the program raises numerous questions about the narcissistic fantasies of these groups. Through interviews with and discussions between, among others, biologists, geneticists, a psychoanalyst, and a philosopher the ethical issues crucial to the cloning debate are outlined. The rapid progress of the technology, and the experiments that have already taken place, is also critically engaged with as notions related to a breakdown between the sexes and generational differences, parent-child bond complications and the blurring of individual identities as well as time that are potentially affected by human cloning are posed and debated. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Clockwork orange [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kubrick, Polaris Productions and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Nominated for four Academy Awards in 1971, ‘A Clockwork Orange’ is a harrowing journey through a near-future world of decaying cities, murderous adolescents and nightmarish technologies of punishment and crime. Set in London it centres around a teenager called Alex (Malcolm McDowell) who is switched on by violence and rape, and surprisingly by Beethoven, and who leads a gang of cool thugs. Based on the novel of the same name by Anthony Burgess. Cast includes Malcolm McDowell, Patrick Magee, Michael Bates and
